metadata.title: Beautiful-Head: Tracing the Evolution of Name-drops and their Relationships within Blogs | by Shaham | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Beautiful-Head: Tracing the Evolution of Name-drops and their Relationships within Blogs
metadata.description: Name-dropping — that ugly, pathetic act of leveraging the name of another to assert one’s own expression — has become, as an accusation, a cultural mechanism to immediately degrade another’s…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: We can even make a game out of feigning ignorance in the face of incessant name-drops
On Name-Dropping: The Mechanisms Behind a Notorious Practice in Social Science and the Humanities
Temporal Dynamics of On-Line Information Streams
Temporal Dynamics of On-Line Information Streams
Alexander Galloway — Media Studies, occasional medium-large posts
Shadi Hamid — Politics, medium-long op-eds, posts, and articles
Elizabeth Bruenig — Politics/Sociology, Culture, medium-long articles

all_paragraphs: Name-dropping — that ugly, pathetic act of leveraging the name of another to assert one’s own expression — has become, as an accusation, a cultural mechanism to immediately degrade another’s expression to merely an annoying pretension. We can even make a game out of feigning ignorance in the face of incessant name-drops. Names, we realize, can be overused. We experience this in normal conversation, on social media, and all sorts of writings — myriad of names, from giants of canons to obscure figures which hold a sanctious status for the writer. Though Webster’s defines it as “the studied but seemingly casual mention of prominent persons as associates done to impress others”, we can imagine name-dropping to extend to any name, even less prominent ones, that serves some sort of utility function for our expression, whether it be increasing our credibility, relatability or reducing possible avenues of criticism.

This project, however, deviates from this shameful reproach to name-dropping to a more generous perspective in which name-dropping can be exploited to inform us of an author’s evolution over time. Before jumping into how I operationalize such an approach, I discuss the 2 theoretical notions that motivate this analysis. Namely,

These 2 theoretical notions, coupled with a learning-in-public context, can be exploited to trace an author’s work based on the name-drops that evolve and form relationships within it. While it can be expanded and tested for a variety of application, this project attempts to show how we could go about creating and illustrating such a process of evolution and association.

I will then present 3 views — a customized animation of a dynamic network, an interactive visualization that summarizes the dynamic network, and a matrix that statically displays the associations between name-drops. I will conclude with some remarks about how the visualizations provide a (grand) ‘informative gesture’ of the author’s work to inform-in-advance and thus, support a reader’s interpretation as well as enhance an author’s ability for self-presentation. Lastly, I present extra demos of visualizing information streams — though they deviate from the specifics of this project.

1 — Motivations (An informal essay outlining the theory behind this approach — this can be skipped by uninterested readers and the visualizations should still make sense, although they will lack their exigence.)
2 — Operationalization (Data collection and network structure)
3 — View X: Animating a Dynamic Network
4 — View Y: A (Summarizing) Diagram of Associations
5 — View Z: Name-drop Matrix
7 — Extras and Other Demos
View X Demo: Austin Kleon’s Dynamic Network Animation
View Y Demo: Austin Kleon’s Diagram of Associations
View Z Demo: Austin Kleon’s Name-drop Matrix
* The informational stream used as data is a scrape of Austin Kleon’s Blog — I explain in the motivations section why I use his posts for this project.

Thorn-R. Kray, in his paper On Name-Dropping: The Mechanisms Behind a Notorious Practice in Social Science and the Humanities, refers to a ‘tipping point’, when “the legit reference to authoritative names… becomes the annoying phenomenon of name-dropping”. (In his context, he is concerned with authoritative names in academic discourse, but we can extend the discussion into the public discourse with little loss.) This implies that there is some threshold where the mechanism of name-dropping (referencing) becomes name-dropping proper. Kray further acknowledges that it is not easy to pin down name-dropping as simply a fallacious appeal to authority — that there is something more peculiar about the act that requires us to perceive it as a social practice rather than a rhetorical logic device.
He refers to Goffman’s classical study The Presentation of Self in Everyday Life:

“When an individual enters the presence of others, they commonly seek to acquire information about him or to bring into play information about him already possessed. […] Information about the individual helps to define the situation, enabling others to know in advance what he will expect of them and what they may expect of him” (Goffman 1956)

Under this social theory, name-dropping still functions as fundamentally ‘a gesture addressed to the audience’, but does not necessarily (solely) contain a sinister motive to ‘impress’. Name-dropping takes the form of a polite social strategy — a means to provide information to the audience in advance, to set expectations, an abstract before the paper.

(Yet, it is also a gamble — as most other lines in an interaction according to Goffman — viable to produce all sorts of impressions within the other [“he’s smart!”, “wow, he’s pretentious”, “but has he even read Deleuze?”], resulting in consequences ranging from a sense of credibility, a power to relate, or a downright embarrassment and shame at having lost our wager.)

Conceiving name-dropping as gestures to audiences meant to inform-in-advance (rather than merely to impress or entertain) gives us our initial motivation: what sort of view of an author could we achieve if, in our analysis, we gave name-dropping the function of a uniquely informative phenomenon compared to other textual phenomenons?

Kray introduces a trust/skepticism-tension in the practice of name-dropping. On one hand, name-dropping, whether to impress or not, is expected to build credibility and yet paradoxically, there is a latent skepticism that one is dropping names only to build credibility. In a strange twist, the conditions for credibility are cause for suspicion if one thinks this appeal for credibility is to mask something non-credible… this contradictory injunction arises from the structure of scientific discourse itself:
“…The young scientist must learn both when to accept the authority of the consensus and when to resist it.” (Overington 1977)

“A requirement like this is paradoxical in nature. The neophyte must learn to follow tradition while remaining sufficiently skeptical toward it. Every failure to meet the expectations connected to it will immediately be noticed. Smirks and curious smiles invoking a feeling of inadequacy will be the punishment for the apprentice’s mistakes. Such cruelty, however, almost appears to be a necessary evil. The demand to ‘think for oneself’ while simultaneously requesting familiarity with a highly exclusive discourse that is supposed to instruct the student ‘how to think’ is a devious double bind.. “ — Kray

Once again, we can stretch this image of science into the more broader public. From academia to the guerrilla warfare that occurs in the replies of tweets, we are bombarded with a social injunction to ‘think for yourself!’, ‘think critically!’ and simultaneously expected to present our credentials (which often come in the form of naming who we are thinking through). Though as paradoxical it may be, this simultaneously acknowledges why we cannot refrain from name-dropping:

“..dropping names is a practice that cannot be avoided precisely because it links us to the intellectual heritage of our discipline’s history. Transforming thoughts of the past into thoughts of the present is, like any good ritual, what name-dropping does.” — Kray

Alan Jacobs, in his book How to Think — written for a general audience — takes it a step further in claiming that “thinking for yourself is impossible”. While Kray ultimately frames a trust-skepticism tension that will exist inevitably and has to be navigated through experience, Jacobs takes the notion to its logical conclusion — that a command to ‘think for yourself’ often just means ‘to think with the people I think through rather than who you are thinking through’. For Jacobs, it would be silly to think there is a ‘thought’ that comes to us untainted by intellectual associations. To go further, Jacobs also makes the bold claim that were thinking for yourself not impossible, it would be undesirable.

To think independently of other human beings is impossible, and if it were possible it would be undesirable. Thinking is necessarily, thoroughly, and wonderfully social. Everything you think is a response to what someone else has thought and said. And when people commend someone for “thinking for herself” they usually mean “ceasing to sound like people I dislike and starting to sound more like people I approve of.” — Alan Jacobs

Thinking is a social act, whether with dead people or the ones sitting next to us — there is no guarantee (and repeated evidence points to the fact) that we would even find pleasure in a thought disconnected from a network of associations. This does not, of course, translate into the phenomenon of name-dropping directly but it does open up the possibility of seeing names as orienting mediums — that is, mediums that construct and shape their content beyond just making it visible.

As mediums, names can become ‘anchors’ of dynamic networks — stabilizing various concepts and topics over time in our knowledge domain as well as structuring how we both perceive and present them. Essentially, this gives us our second motivation. Most network analysis have tried not to favour one textual phenomenon over another or introduce hierarchies (part of a larger notion to “let the data talk” without interference of theory), but if names are truly privileged (as mediums governing all other concepts), network analysis techniques that rely largely on counts, aggregates, sums, etc. may not reveal their special status.

Therefore, conceptualizing name-drops as mediums that anchor concepts, coupled with Goffman’s implication of names as a uniquely informative social strategy, provides the underlying drive for this project — which is to attempt visualizations of dynamic information networks that privileges name-drops as the mediums described above.

Though we have our motivation, I would like to use this section to caution that while this is a sort of “in Praise of Name-dropping” project, I am not eliminating the possibility of fallacious or vulgar uses that cause us annoyance. I do agree with Klay’s assessment that there is a ‘tipping point’ when we label something name-dropping rather than mere referencing. However, I am bringing into question our determination of that point — specifically, the accusation that someone is name-dropping seems to have equal potential for sinister motives than the actual act of name-dropping.

It seems that what separates the annoying phenomenon of name-dropping from something less annoying is really our judgement of the name-dropper’s dark, deep intention — are they gesturing at this name to impress us or is it more akin to paying homage to the thinkers they are thinking through? In fact, stripping name-dropping of any vulgar desire to impress extraordinary appearance of oneself, but keeping more or less the same mechanism (i.e. alluding to someone else, who serves some sort of function for your expression), the act of name-dropping is reduced to little more than banal “boilerplate for expression” — acts we may call ‘giving credit’, ‘referencing’, or ‘citing sources’. Nevertheless, it is boilerplate we gladly tolerate in society because it provides safety from the even more unfathomable alternative of plagiarism.

So I sense an equally paradoxical tension in the social-shame of name dropping.. on one hand, we are required to present our references to safeguard ourselves from the crime of plagiarism and one the other hand, there is an overflowing pressure to ‘present our own thoughts’, and the fear that ‘name-dropping correlates with intellectual insecurity’. In fact, if Alan Jacobs is right in that thinking for ourselves is impossible and undesirable — and I tend to think he is — the question could radically transform into ‘why aren’t we name-dropping more?’ (under a certain notion of plagiarism and intellectual property).

Letham, in his glorious essay The Ecstasy of Influence , boldly acknowledges this tension and argues for a radical embrace, arguing that denying the inevitability of plagiaristic activity is a ‘source hypocrisy’. I quote his assertion directly in fear I couldn’t do justice in relating it second-hand:

Any text is woven entirely with citations, references, echoes, cultural languages, which cut across it through and through in a vast stereophony. The citations that go to make up a text are anonymous, untraceable, and yet already read; they are quotations without inverted commas. The kernel, the soul — let us go further and say the substance, the bulk, the actual and valuable material of all human utterances — is plagiarism. For substantially all ideas are secondhand, consciously and unconsciously drawn from a million outside sources, and daily used by the garnerer with a pride and satisfaction born of the superstition that he originated them; whereas there is not a rag of originality about them anywhere except the little discoloration they get from his mental and moral caliber and his temperament, and which is revealed in characteristics of phrasing. Old and new make the warp and woof of every moment. There is no thread that is not a twist of these two strands. By necessity, by proclivity, and by delight, we all quote. Neurological study has lately shown that memory, imagination, and consciousness itself is stitched, quilted, pastiched. If we cut-and-paste our selves, might we not forgive it of our artworks?

Furthering, or perhaps stealing, this thought, Austin Kleon, through his project Steal Like an Artist (which in my reading expands beyond his book and up to his virtual identity) provides pragmatic guidelines for this “cut-and-paste” methodology of creativity and ideation. He outlines it succinctly in a Good-Theft / Bad-Theft comparison:

In this sense, name-dropping is almost good manners — a means of not only fairly crediting but also honouring your ‘heroes’. (Note that in this project’s conceptualizing of name-drops, they are not necessarily ‘heroes’ — as mediums, they could be anti-heroes, habitual objects of critique, etc.). So far you will notice that I have referred to a form of name-dropping which some might be inclined to view as simply referencing — but referencing is closer to the notion of a formal citation, rather than an informal, casual, good-theft mention like name-dropping. As Kleon emphasizes: “If it feels cheap or wrong to you, it probably is. I advocate an “elevator gut check” for one’s own work: If you met the artist you’re stealing from in a stalled elevator, would they shake your hand or punch you in the face?” It’s not too difficult to apply this advice to the tension of name-dropping itself.

Therefore, through the notions outlined in Letham’s essay and Kleon’s work (which is very popular among artists, writers, etc.), we can also observe personal theoretical frameworks — that govern someone’s writings and other outputs — incentivizing name-dropping. This adds support to treating name-drops as an object of analysis as well as provides us with a context where such an analysis may flourish: a learning-in-public context. Learning-in-public is a loose term I use to describe an increasing trend within blogs and micro-blogs (social media) to document one’s learnings (and thus the mediums they learn through). Kleon self-ascribes this process to his online output, referencing C.S. Lewis:

“I write for the unlearned about things in which I am unlearned myself… It often happens that two schoolboys can solve difficulties in their work for one another better than the master can… I write as one amateur to another, talking about difficulties I have met, or lights I have gained…” — C.S. Lewis

“This is the way I’ve always tried to approach writing, teaching, or speaking on stage: not as an expert, but as a fellow student. I’m trying to learn in the open. I’m letting others look over my shoulder while I figure things out.” — Kleon

The drive to ‘learn in the open’, coupled with our discussion of good-theft and influence, provide an excellent context in which an analysis of name-dropping can be both accessible — authors are incentivized to name-drop and list out their mediums in their posts — and meaningful — an analysis of those mediums would, in turn, be valuable in understanding the evolution of the author’s works and thoughts.
This also leads me to the choice of using Austin Kleon’s blogs as the dataset for this visualization.

Kleinberg’s Temporal Dynamics of On-Line Information Streams is an excellent survey paper of the kinds of problems we encounter when dealing with information streams (through an informational network perspective). As Kleinberg demonstrates, tracking the evolution of topics over time, recognizing ‘events’ within streams, and informational visualization are all important aspects of the field — and this project touches all of these slightly. As mentioned earlier, fundamentally, this work is closer to providing a possible form of information visualization — one that privileges name-drops within an information network. Though certainly not close to the rigiour of formal studies — I don’t really ‘test’ anything — , this is an informal exploration into what an approach might look like — and the interestingness of its results — if we were to visualize through a social theory of name-drops rather than a completely data-oriented approach.

“What are the right techniques for dealing with the temporal dynamics of information streams? Some of the complexities inherent in such streams can be seen in the paradigmatic examples of news and e-mail. Each provides a reader with a sequence of documents exhibiting a braided and episodic character: braided, in the sense that many parallel, topically coherent streams are merged and interwoven into the single stream that the reader sees; and episodic, in the sense that topics generally grow in intensity over a temporally coherent period, and then fade again. Despite these twin sources of complexity, however, these information streams in their raw forms lack any explicit organizing structure beyond the granularity of individual articles or messages. Thus, a first step in working with such information streams is to define appropriate structures that abstract their intertwined topics, their multiple bursty episodes, and their long-term trends.” — Kleinberg, Temporal Dynamics of On-Line Information Streams

There are numerous steps involved in generating this analysis, each with intricate technical parameter tunings to get meaningful results. Since I don’t ultimately develop anything new here — but simply cut-and-paste various data mining, information visualization, and network science techniques — I will only go over the high level technical steps.

The data for this project comes in the format of a stream of time stamped documents. Specifically, I scrape Austin Kleon’s blog site to get each blog post (we will call this a document) and when it was published.
Extracting Name-drops and Content To get our units of analysis, I pass each document through a parser, POS tagged, and a page rank algorithm to get the following:

Generating Initial NetworkFor each name-drop that appears together in the same document, I formulate a connection between them with a relative weight of how important both terms are. Doing this for every pair of name-drops generated a network of nodes and edges. Since I am interested in name-drops that serve the most medium-like role, I measure each node’s information-centrality — which calculates relative to edge weight — and extract the top 5%. Presumably, this provides us with the name-drops that have served the most central role over time.

Note that name-drops other than the extracted 5% are treated like content. Essentially, these other name-drops, though mediums in their own right, are not strong enough to separate from the content for the sake of these visualizations.

Following the media theorist Marshall McLuhan, we can also conceptualize that “the “content” of any medium is always another medium”. Therefore, we are really just trying to extract the most relevant mediums — name-drops, nouns, proper nouns, are all mediums in a sense — and labeling the rest as “content”.
Similarly, for each time step, we formulate connections between Name-drops and content based on if they appear in blog posts together. This gives us our dynamic network.
Demo: Austin Kleon’s Dynamic Network Animation

The first view I present is semi-informative — it presents a story, but not seamlessly, though I include it nevertheless — and semi-art. The idea here is to create an animation that emphasizes specific properties of the network of Name-drops and content as it evolves over time.

The general idea is to visualize when name-drops appear, their weight in the author’s texts based on their vertical position and size and what is the specificity of the content they connect with based on their horizontal position. This results in an animation that shows the story of name-drops as mediums, navigating their place in an author’s knowledge domain and information stream dependant on the content that is thought and presented through them.
Demo: Austin Kleon’s Diagram of Associations

If we remove the animating factor from the previous view and summarize association weights, we can visualize a summarizing diagram that visualizes the influence and associations between the name-drops (author’s mediums) as well as content.
This view works interactively, the idea is to hover over a name-drop node to see its past or future influence on other name-drops.
How to read this view after interaction:

In general, hovering over a name-drop node Z highlights all the other nodes in the diagram that influence (in the future) or have been influenced (in the past) by node Z. This influence is a weighted measure calculated through connections with content-nodes taking into account the significance of the content node and name-drops in the author’s works. Theoretically, this visual displays the influence between mediums over time — emphasizing the progression of influences that shape the author’s works — as well as the large concepts that are widely discussed.

Finally, if we further summarize the summarizing diagram, we can remove content nodes from the view and simply display the associations between name-drops. This serves as the simplest, most readable visual among the 3 that attempts to express the quickest history of an author’s name-drops. The matrix, even without a detailed read, points to a ‘gut-feeling’ of how authors may work through their mediums.

In general, hovering over a cell highlights the relevant name-drops whose association it represents. Practically speaking, looking at a column of cells for a given name-drop X on the horizontal axis reads as “how strongly past connections of name-drop X influenced the future connections of other name-drops”. Inversely, looking at a row of cells for a given name-drop Y on the vertical axis reads as “how strong were the connections of name-drop Y influenced by the past connections of other name-drops”. (Connections means the links between a name-drop and content nodes and influence is measured the same way as previous views — through a weighted measure of the connections with shared content nodes). Theoretically, this visual emphasizes both the major name-drops as well as what and when the name-drops are influencing. Furthermore, as the matrix is not symmetrical — the influence of name-drop X on name-drop Y does not equal the influence of Y on X — the visual depicts the reciprocity of influence between name-drops and any significant imbalances.
In this section, I want to write out some general thoughts on the limitations of this approach and the insights these visualizations can provide.

Perhaps the immediate effect of the presented visuals stems directly from the motivation — they serve as a (grand) ‘informative gesture’ that quickly disseminates the image of the self that authors wish to depict to their readers. By eliminating excess connections and scoping down to what can be safely visualized, this project tries to present the significantly habitual moves within an information stream (in this case, an author’s blog). By visualizing habits in such a way, a reader can use these visualizations to quickly gauge multiple properties of an information stream, including:

Thinking through these above properties and many others that are difficult to enumerate, combined with Kray and Goffman’s theoretical notion of name-drops as informational gestures to inform-in-advance, we can conceptualize the visualizations as a grand informative gesture. As a grand gesture, the visualizations inform and prepare the audience for the information they can expect in advance through an aggregate view of the history of name-drops. Note that such a gesture does not necessarily rely on a reader’s knowledge of the name-drops — name-drops in everyday conversation seldom do — but present an ‘image’ of the author (Goffman’s self-presentation theory). This image itself is a medium through which we can perceive the author’s information stream — as a crude, intuitive example, seeing a matrix of a variety of weighty name-drops with a spread of influence vs. a matrix of a single high-weight name-drop with little influence can immediately give us a different idea of what we can expect from the author’s texts. Furthermore, these visualizations (especially the matrix and summarizing diagram) display the structure of the system of ‘anchors’ that orient an author’s discussion — in this sense, we can perceive a sense of how topics may reoccur within an information stream over time.

Further hypothesis can arise and we can expect that if we were to look at multiple name-drop networks at a large scale, we could extract patterns and categorize various properties of information streams. We could even conceive of finding ratios, thresholds, and plateaus of the properties of name-drop dynamic networks that could be observed to cluster information streams into different types or possibly model them to forecast information flows.

These visualization — especially the matrix — can also function as blog-summarization. Other attempts — Blog Antenna — have tried to summarize personal blogs with a visual through a self-similarity topic analysis, but once again, privileging name-drops may serve as a more sound theoretical structure.
Other Demos can be viewed @ beautiful-head.appspot.com
The name Beautiful-Head is a reference to The National’s song Beautiful Head in which Berninger sings:

“Redefining yourself Designing yourselfYou haven’t looked at me foreverGot a diagram of your associationsA strategyYou’re weighing your optionsWhat would you trade me for?You’re measuring me latelyAnd I can tellAnd I can tell I’m losing weightYou’re measuring me latelyYou’re dressing me” — The National, Beautiful Head Verse 2
Uncanny, no? I propose the entire song be heard from an informational-network perspective as elucidating the role of name-drops in Goffman’s self-presentation social theory.
Though this analysis has limitations for news and/or smaller information streams — as I explain in the limitations section — I still ran it on some other authors and blogs for fun — just to see.
Alexander Galloway — Media Studies, occasional medium-large posts
Shadi Hamid — Politics, medium-long op-eds, posts, and articles
Other Views: Shadi Hamid’s Demo Visualizations
Elizabeth Bruenig — Politics/Sociology, Culture, medium-long articles
Other Views: Elizabeth Bruenig’s Demo Visualizations

Possibly due to the low number of posts, but there is a pretty visible asymmetry indicating that other than for a few key candidates (Bernie, Warren, etc.), older name-drops influence future name-drops but there is little back-referencing. This could be structural property of culture/opinion writing where information streams are constantly addressing current events and thus generally moving forward without changing past opinions (unlike the learning-in-public blogs).

This project is customized for blog posts, but I ran it for fun on some twitter accounts that — I consider — use their feeds in somewhat of a learning-in-public context (mix of content on religion (Islam), philosophy, and politics). Note that due to Twitter data collecting limitations, this isn’t a complete history of a user but recent ~3200 tweets/RTs + replies.

Lastly, I present my own Twitter’s Name-drop Matrix — quite an embarrassing self-image compared to everyone else in this post... (I certainly haven’t always used twitter in a very learning-in-public way, but I’ve started to more recently).

The matrix has definitely caught all the major name-drops I perform on Twitter and it has accurately reflected my later change into a more connected, learning performance with stronger associations at the bottom right of the matrix.
Thank you for reading. Feel free to contact me on Twitter if you have any questions or thoughts you’d like to discuss.
If you think there is another blog or information stream that could be interesting to visualize through this project, let me know and I’ll see what I can do!
